revised_title: ATP-Activated Conductances in Schwann Cells: Implications for Neuro-Glial Communication
tldr: This study investigates the effects of adenosine 5'-triphosphate (ATP) on the electrical properties of mouse Schwann cells. The researchers found that external ATP activates a conductance that carries both cations (potassium and calcium) and anions (chloride). This ATP-activated conductance resembles a P2-mediated response in its kinetics, agonist potency, and blockade by suramin, but differs in its requirement for high concentrations of ATP and the activation of a cationic as well as anionic conductance.
